Fine then, Glenn, here it is plain answer:

a. Yes if you define RESTFulnes=
s as a badge that certifies you follow the rules. Yes, you can earn that ba=
dge only in your server and forget about the client.

b. NO, if you define =
RESTFulness as the achievement of the expected quality properties you seek =
for when using REST. And that NO is because the rules are made to achieve a=
 way of interaction between the components, and one of those components is =
the client. 

In other words, client matters.

As I had been posting here, =
one component may not behave by the rules, but if that is free license the =
architect is aware of and it is reasonable so that the impact will not brea=
k the business goals, that is fine. But if you need a system where clients =
behave correctly, and you don't control the clients, then your architecture=
 must have controls and policy enforcement to avoid those spoiled clients f=
rom ruining you day. If not, your system will not get to its goal and it wi=
ll be a failure, even if your server is made by the REST book. 

REST stops=
 when it defines the constrains and promises quality properties, but life g=
oes on, and the rest of the system is still to be constructed. Having just =
one server following REST rules is just one step. And let me clarify this: =
It should not be part of the server's job to assure the client is working a=
s it should. It may help, but we can have several layers that can add contr=
ols and enforce policies. There is far more in an system than just one serv=
er and one client.

Finally: I feel the discussion confuses an App, with a =
Server, with a System, with a API. When we talk about a server doing its pa=
rt, sounds like we are talking about an API. Is it that? Yes, we can expose=
 a REST like API, but then we need a client to consume it. A system is some=
thing far more complex, where all components, including clients, may affect=
 other components. Butterfly effect, that is called.

Well, this was not a =
short and sweet answer, and I feel I'm repeating myself here. But it is tru=
ly a more deep discussion than just earning a badge.

Cheers

William.
